channel.title: NYT > Home Page
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: City Room: New York Today: Let It Rain
item.description: What you need to know for Wednesday: a rainy day, a workshop for street trees, and a mayoral selfie.
item.dc:creator: By ANNIE CORREAL

item.title: Silicon Valley’s Youth Problem
item.description: In start-up land, the young barely talk to the old (and vice versa). That makes for a lot of cool apps. But great technology? Not so much.
item.dc:creator: By YIREN LU

item.title: Ukraine’s Interim Leader Seeks Aid in Washington
item.description: Ukraine’s interim prime minister, Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk, is to meet Wednesday with President Obama and congressional leaders at a critical moment for his country.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: Video: Times Minute | Prostitution in the U.S.
item.description: Also on the Minute, stimulant use in the United States rises and class is in session at the New York Times Wine School.
item.dc:creator: By CARRIE HALPERIN

item.title: Cancale Journal: In France, a Quest to Convert a Sea Snail Plague Into a Culinary Pleasure
item.description: The community of Cancale now finds itself torn between disgust and relief at an entrepreneur’s project to fish and sell the sea snails for consumption.
item.dc:creator: By LALITA CLOZEL
item.media:credit: Catalina Martin-Chico for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jean-François Dore raked up the Atlantic slipper shells that cover the seabed in the waters off Cancale in France in an attempt to protect the area’s oyster and mussel farms from the invasive sea snails.

item.title: In-Depth Report Details Economics of Sex Trade
item.description: The study, commissioned by the Justice Department, focused on the business side, rather than on consumers, of the underground sex business.
item.dc:creator: By ANNIE LOWREY

item.title: Report Says Medication Use Is Rising for Adults With Attention Disorder
item.description: Some experts said the report indicated that the disorder is being diagnosed and treated with medication in children far too often, and that steeply rising diagnoses among adults might portend similar problems.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN SCHWARZ

item.title: Health Care Enrollment Falls Short of Goal, With Deadline Approaching
item.description: The number of people who signed up for private health insurance under the Affordable Care Act in February declined for the second month in a row.
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT PEAR

item.title: Wanted by Ecuador, 2 Brothers Make Mark in U.S. Campaigns
item.description: Donations in two fugitives’ case creates the appearance of a conflict of interest for the Obama administration, which has rejected Ecuador’s extradition request for the men.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:credit: Angel Valentin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Roberto Isaias, who has withstood extradition requests from Ecuador, in Miami last month.

item.title: 49ers Acquire Jonathan Martin From Dolphins
item.description: Jonathan Martin is returning to familiar territory, months after he accused a teammate of bullying and left the Miami Dolphins.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Victory in Florida Race Bolsters Midterm Hopes for Republicans
item.description: The Republican candidate, David Jolly, defeated the Democrat, Alex Sink, to fill a congressional seat on Florida’s Gulf Coast.
item.dc:creator: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ
item.media:credit: Cherie Diez/The Tampa Bay Times, via Associated Press

item.title: Obama Team Debates How to Punish Russia
item.description: As President Obama searches for a way to contain and ultimately reverse Russia’s invasion of southern Ukraine without using force, his team finds itself torn over just how far to go using economic weapons.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: Prime Minister Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk of Ukraine will visit the White House on Wednesday for a show of solidarity.

item.title: Obama Will Seek Broad Expansion of Overtime Pay
item.description: President Obama this week will direct the Labor Department to revamp its regulations to require overtime pay for millions of workers.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and STEVEN GREENHOUSE
item.media:description: President Obama plans to use his executive authority to change the nation’s overtime rules.

item.title: Political Killings Still Plaguing Post-Qaddafi Libya
item.description: Political divisions within the elected General National Congress, with groups backed by rival militias, have rendered the appointed government almost powerless.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: People opposing an extension of the national government’s powers blocked a main street in the eastern Libyan city of Benghazi last month.

item.title: Clinton Aide Linked to Campaign Scandal
item.description: A businessman embroiled in a campaign finance scandal communicated with an adviser to Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton on an illegal canvassing effort to bolster Mrs. Clinton’s 2008 campaign, court documents say.
item.dc:creator: By AMY CHOZICK

item.title: As Homeless Shelter Population Rises, Advocates Push Mayor on Policies
item.description: A record 53,615 people slept in shelters in January, according to the Coalition for the Homeless, which is hopeful Mayor Bill de Blasio will reverse a trend of rising homelessness it blames on his predecessor.
item.dc:creator: By NIKITA STEWART
item.media:description: Betsy-Ann, an outreach worker, speaking with a homeless woman in Penn Station in January.

item.title: Conflict Erupts in Public Rebuke on C.I.A. Inquiry
item.description: Senator Dianne Feinstein, the chairwoman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, said the C.I.A. searched computers being used by committee staff members to investigate the agency’s interrogation tactics.
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI and JONATHAN WEISMAN
item.media:description: Senator Dianne Feinstein, the chairwoman of the Senate intelligence committee.

item.title: Justice Dept. Is Said to Look at G.M. Actions on Safety Flaws
item.description: The investigation is the latest in a widening series into G.M.’s handling of faulty ignition switches in its Chevrolet Cobalt sedan and other cars that the company says are linked to 31 accidents and 13 deaths.
item.dc:creator: By BILL VLASIC and BEN PROTESS
item.media:description: The 2005 Chevy Cobalt, shown at a Detroit car show, is among 1.6 million cars recalled by G.M.

item.title: At Trial of Bin Laden Relative, Witness Describes Meeting 9/11 Mastermind
item.description: An operative for Al Qaeda offered an intimate account of his interactions with Osama bin Laden and Khalid Shaikh Mohammed in the terrorism trial of Sulaiman Abu Ghaith.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER
item.media:credit: Al-Jazeera, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Top Disney TV Official to Step Down
item.description: Anne M. Sweeney, one of the most powerful women in the entertainment industry, will leave in 2015 after 18 years at the company to become a television director.
item.dc:creator: By BROOKS BARNES and BILL CARTER
item.media:description: Ms. Sweeney arriving at The 86th Academy Awards. She played a direct role in a ratings surge at ABC News and recently helped Disney complete a widely applauded programming deal with Dish Network.

item.title: About New York: Removing 9/11 Artifacts From New Jersey’s Nest of Political Patronage
item.description: Steel from the World Trade Center site will no longer be handled by Gov. Chris Christie’s political appointees at the Port Authority, but by the agency’s professional staff.
item.category: Port Authority of New York and New Jersey
item.dc:creator: By JIM DWYER
item.media:credit: Michael Nagle for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dozens of pieces of steel have been stored in a hangar at Kennedy International Airport for more than a decade.

item.title: Judge Hears Arguments on Subpoenas to Christie Associates
item.description: Two former aides to Gov. Chris Christie have refused to turn over documents related to the lane closings scandal, saying it would violate their right against self-incrimination.
item.dc:creator: By KATE ZERNIKE
item.media:description: Bridget Anne Kelly, Gov. Chris Christie’s former deputy chief of staff, with Michael Critchley, her lawyer, after a court hearing in Trenton on Tuesday.

item.title: Stars’ Peverley Has Tests After Collapsing in Game
item.description: Dallas center Rich Peverley, 31, who has a history of heart issues, spent Tuesday at a hospital after collapsing in Monday’s game against Columbus.
item.dc:creator: By JEFF Z. KLEIN
item.media:credit: Jerome Miron/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
item.media:description: A view of the scoreboard after the game between the Stars and the Blue Jackets was postponed.

item.title: How a Court Secretly Evolved, Extending U.S. Spies’ Reach
item.description: Leaked documents add new details to a secret body of law that the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court has developed since it began to broaden its role in 2001.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE and LAURA POITRAS

item.title: N.S.A. Nominee Promotes Cyberwar Units
item.description: Citing cyberattacks on the new Ukrainian government, President Obama’s nominee to run the National Security Agency, Vice Adm. Michael S. Rogers, said “cyber will be an element of every crisis.”
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
